tourName: Ultimate Two-Week Gastronomy Tour of Peru
placesVisited: Lima, Arequipa, Lake Titicaca, Cusco, Sacred Valley, Machu Picchu, Madre de Dios
generalInfo: Savor the authentic flavors of Peru while you venture to the scenic landscapes of the ancient Inca Empire. Street vendors in Cusco grin from ear to ear as they offer buttery thick choclo corn. In the foothills of the Andes mountains, indulge in heavenly, seasoned meat and potatoes that are cooked over hot burning stones. Amazonian staples like jaune will entice you with a flavorful mix of rice, chicken, and a delicate presentation inside banana leaves. Of course, there is no better way to learn about Peru's famed citrusy ceviche than to roll up your sleeves and get cooking alongside an expert chef. During these delicious two weeks, you will experience all of Peru’s unique, gastronomic highlights.

dayInfo.title: Lima – Touchdown and Sunset Stroll
dayInfo.description: Lima opens up along a pristine turquoise-blue coastline and welcomes visitors from around the world with arms stretched open. Locals carry on with the hustle and bustle of daily life in the third largest metropolitan area in the Americas, which is home to one-third of the country's population. Cars eagerly honk as they weave their way between other cars, bikes, and tour buses. Young children skip in the distance past carefree couples who are leisurely strolling through the Parque del Amor . Street vendors perform what looks like a circus plate twirling act as they tend to dozens of skewers of meat, rotating each perfectly on smoky hot coals until they are golden brown. As you step foot on the tarmac, the fresh scent of sea salt and citrusy, lemon-lime aromas will waft in your direction. Your private transport will escort you to your five-star, luxury accommodation in the prestigious neighborhood of San Blas. By mid-afternoon, the hot Peruvian sun will begin to wane in the sky, which is perhaps the best time of the day to experience the city in its full beauty. Sky gliders sway back and forth in the distance against the backdrop of a warm, yellow-orange horizon, and talented musicians serenade passersby and families that are set out on picnic blankets in the grassy, public parks. At sunset, you can choose from a plethora of decadent dining options, each with magnificent views of the Pacific Ocean's iridescent, rolling waves.

dayInfo.title: Lima – City Tour and Private Ceviche Cooking Class
dayInfo.description: There is no better way to experience the intrigue of the nation's capital than to partake in a captivating tour of the city's most prized jewels. You will join your expert guide mid-morning in front of your hotel and will start in the heart of the distinguished Miraflores. You will amble along the alluring, grassy cliffs of Parque Grau where cyclists and skateboarders may enjoy a scenic ride and couples relax on mosaic-tiled benches that overlook the seaside. Continue to the Miraflores Lighthouse, which was rebuilt nearly fifty years ago as homage to the original lighthouse that was built in the year 1900 in the city of Punta Coles. The dotted white skyscrapers of this modern neighborhood carve out only a small portion of the city's rich history. You will follow your guide to the elegant, cobbled streets of the Old City where you can photograph the exquisite post-colonial architecture of Basílica y Convento de San Francisco de Lima and the Government Palace of Peru. You can stand beneath the shady palm trees of the central Plaza de Armas as you admire the vibrant pink and yellow facades of the Spanish design. No visit to Lima can be complete without a delectable taste of the nation's utmost point of pride: ceviche . You will join a dynamic cooking class in the heart of the Old City that is led by a renowned, local chef to learn the secrets behind this enticing, seafood masterpiece. You will crunch into tangy onions, tomatoes, peppers, and shrimp that are topped with tantalizing cilantro and hot, chili garlic paste.

dayInfo.title: Arequipa – Visit to Santa Catalina Monastery and San Camilo Market
dayInfo.description: Of course, the grandeur of Peruvian gastronomy extends far beyond the coastal lowland plains on the western shores. You will travel inland to the post-Columbian city of Arequipa to the south. Pristine white facades of downtown buildings flank the central plaza while vibrant red-orange walls pop out from unassuming alcoves. You will take a short flight and touchdown in Arequipa mid-morning. Then, you will follow your guide on a customized tour of key architectural and historical points of interests. It will be impossible to miss the allure of the Santa Catalina Monastery because of its blood orange exterior that warmly welcomes public visitors. In fact, much of the interior passageways and tunnels are also donned in the same vibrant, rich hues that will make you feel as if you are stepping foot in a fanciful storybook. Inside, you will marvel at the ornate religious artifacts and discover the riveting blend of indigenous culture and Spanish influence after the great conquests of the 16th and 17th century. At lunchtime, you can bite into the flavors of this hearty, mountain cuisine that will be sure to warm you up and fill your belly. You can sample the famed rocoto relleno , which is a deliciously sweet, red pepper that is stuffed with meat and eggs and topped with a layer of oozing, melted cheese. You can also enjoy a heavenly spoonful of Arequipa's adobo stew. In the afternoon, you can get lost in the effervescent San Camilo Market where locals call out daily deals with the velocity of a seasoned auctioneer. Electrifying yellows and greens of produce pop against the clay tile floors, and friendly-faced vendors cut open the milky white chirimoya fruit to entice hungry customers. As the day wears on, you can quench your thirst at one of many colorful fruit stands that are inside the market where you can watch vendors squeeze fresh, frothy mango, papaya, and guayaba juices before your eyes. Once you have received your fill of adventure for the day, your private guide will transfer you back to your luxurious accommodation.

dayInfo.title: Lake Titicaca – Uros' Floating Islands and Fresh Trout Lakeside Dinner
dayInfo.description: As the new day breaks, a new hideaway of delectable eats will be calling your name. You will carry on your foodie tour to the serene town of Puno at the base of Lake Titicaca. In the morning, you will board a cruise boat and spend several hours touring the highest navigable lake in the world: Lake Titicaca. The unique lake is straddled between the national border of Peru and neighboring Bolivia. You can even catch a glimpse of the spirited marine life that flocks in the tranquil waters below. You will step foot atop the curious, floating islands that were built by the Uros people hundreds of years ago. As the Inca Empire gained power and land, the Uros were forced to flee from the valleys of south-central Peru. Consequently, they sought refuge in the Puno region, but instead of staking claim along the water's edge, they created buoyant island colonies that they fashioned from thick layers of reeds that are native to the lake. You will partake in a reed weaving demonstration and peruse jewelry and textiles that have been handmade by the Uros people. In the late afternoon, you will sit down lakeside for a scenic meal that overlooks the sparkling waters of Lake Titicaca. A renowned local chef will serve you the region's prized delicacy: fresh lake trout that are seasoned with expert execution and topped with refreshing slices of lemon.

dayInfo.title: Cusco – Qorikancha, Plaza de Armas, and Restaurant and Bar Tapas
dayInfo.description: You will venture to the birthplace of the Inca Empire to experience the ultimate convergence of Peruvian food and culture. You will also wind through the cobblestoned streets of post-colonial Cusco and past extraordinary relics of the ancient Empire. Soon, you will arrive at your hotel in the white stucco neighborhood of San Blas where you can settle in with perhaps the most symbolic of all cusqueño delicacies: mate de coca tea. This light green tea, which is made from Peru's endemic coca leaf, is used for spiritual practice and is said to offset hunger and the effects of altitude sickness. Early in the afternoon, you will meet your expert guide at the Plaza de Armas. The ornate, central fountain trickles in the background, and hurried residents make their way to mass at the adorned Cusco Cathedral. As you peel off towards Avenida del Sol , the wafting, buttery smells of choclo , which is a thick-kernel corn, will fascinate your senses. It is the perfect salty-sweet snack as you meander down Cusco's central artery to reach Qorikancha . Here, you will admire the original gold leafing and beautiful floral landscaping of this Sun Temple, which not only withstood Spanish invasion but three devastating earthquakes as well. After a relaxing break at your hotel accommodations, you will convene once again at the Plaza de Armas for a tapas tour of Cusco's Novo-Andean cuisine, which blends traditional ingredients with modern-day flavors from around the world. You will begin at one of the many luxurious restaurants along the plaza's perimeter to sample antojos de queso en salsa de maracuya, which is a cheese and spinach dish that is marinated in a sweet passion fruit sauce. Later, you can venture to the neighborhoods of San Blas and beyond to indulge in a quinoa risotto or potato stew.

dayInfo.title: Cusco – Tambomachay, Saqsaywaman Ruins, and Cuy Sampler
dayInfo.description: The next morning, you will depart Cusco's city limits to uncover some of the Inca Empire's most renowned jewels. You will begin at the site of Tambomachay, which is just a short, 20-minute drive from Cusco. Here, you can behold the ruins of the former Inca bathing spas. For hundreds of years, nobility luxuriated in the natural spring waters that were redirected to the site via aqueducts and other water channels. Later, you will continue on the same winding dirt road to the ruins of Saqsaywaman. Among the Inca Empire's grandeur is a palpable sense of military might. The remnants of the Saqsaywaman fortress is a testament to the fortitude of Inca structure and design and its ability to evade outside threats until the fateful Spanish Conquest. In the evening, you will travel to a nearby village for a warm welcoming and smoky outdoor barbecue around a crackling fire as you look out on the starry sky and serene city below. Here, your cooks will serve you the most authentic of Andean dishes: cuy , or grilled guinea pig, which is considered a delicacy in the region. This hearty meal is served with a side of peppers and tomatoes, which is perfect for satisfying a big appetite. After dinner, you will wind back down the dirt path towards your cozy hotel accommodations in San Blas.

dayInfo.title: Sacred Valley – Chinchero, Moray, Maras, and Pachamama Barbecue
dayInfo.description: Today marks the first day in your journey to Peru's coveted ruins of Machu Picchu. You will start your day early in front of your hotel where you will meet your local guide. As you begin to weave along the central byway of the Sacred Valley, steep Andean mountain peaks will fall into the rearview mirror, and grassy green pastures will rise to the forefront. The intense Andean sun may shine brightly on the luscious foliage, and the water of the Urubamba River may sparkle with every churn. You can bump along the entrance to your first stop in the Valley at Chinchero. This village, glowing white with post-colonial stucco design, was once the coveted resort town for Cusqueño nobility. Today, the village warmly welcomes visitors from around the world. First, you will sit in on a natural yarn dyeing class to learn about indigenous dyeing techniques that are still used to this day. Then you can get comfortable on an outdoor patio for a delectable home-cooked lunch that is locally known as pachamanca . This dish, which literally means "Earth Oven" in Peru's native Quechua language, entices diners with its delicious beef, pork, and lamb mixture that is served with fava beans and potatoes. As its name suggests, this meal is cooked over hot coals in a hole that has been dug into the ground and then covered with corn husks. In the evening, you will visit the fascinating sites of Moray and Maras, both of which were integral parts of Incan innovation. At first, in Moray, Inca agriculturalists developed a practice that is known as agricultural terracing, whereby steep, step-like layers are built into a hillside to allow for optimal farming and irrigation. These concentric circles serve as stunning examples of Inca ingenuity. Secondly, at Maras, you will get to see the sparkling salt basins that were built hundreds of years ago as the Inca harvested an abundant salt supply. Even to this day, salt is harvested from the same large, cascading basins.

dayInfo.title: Sacred Valley – Ollantaytambo and Mate de Coca tea Culture Class
dayInfo.description: The majestic landscape of the Sacred Valley's rolling, green hills will invite you for a thrilling second day of exploration that will be full of fresh, regional bites. After a well-rested night beneath a blanket of a clear, starry night sky, your private transport will take you to the acclaimed ruins of Ollantaytambo. You can join your tour guide at the base of the former citadel as you unpack the site's fascinating history. You will start at the beautiful agricultural terraces that cascade from the hillside of Ollantaytambo's central plaza to the Urubamba and Patakancha Rivers, which are located deep in the cradle of the valley. You will behold the carefully constructed quarries and perfectly positioned storehouses that are set high into the mountainside to ward off decay. As you trek to the storehouses, you will learn more about the Incas' line of defense as they thwarted attempted attacks by the Spanish in the 16th and 17th centuries. In the afternoon, you will travel to a quaint, local village where you will sip on the delicious mate de coca tea as you discover the cultural nuances of the herbal remedy to this day. As you take three of the leaves, your expert instructor will teach you how the Andean people place the leaves between two fingers, fan them out towards the sky, and then blow on each leaf to give thanks to Pachamama , or "Mother Earth." Then, you will take a bite of the leaf as the locals do to for a boost of daily caffeine. Your guide will then prepare steeping cups of the herbal tea for you as you look out on the stunning terraces of Ollantaytambo that are visible in the distance.

dayInfo.title: Aguas Calientes – UNESCO Ruins Summit
dayInfo.description: As the sun begins to climb in the sky, you will step aboard a luxury train car that will be equipped with a 360-degree view of the Valley as you make your way to the UNESCO World Heritage site of Machu Picchu. You will encounter iridescent waterways, chug past small villages with roaming cattle and vicuñas, and glide across lovely, orange bridges that pop against the green-blue backdrop. Mid-morning, you will arrive at the base city of Aguas Calientes. Here, you will be met by your local, private transport who will escort you to your five-star hotel that will be nestled into the foothills of the Andes Mountains. Once you are checked in, you can relax on your private balcony as you admire the hushed mountain village below. Then, as the sun draws to its peak, you will meet your guide in front of your hotel who will accompany you to the entrance of the ruins. You will ascend steep, switchback roads in your private transport as you draw nearer. Less than an hour later, you will step off at the grounds of Machu Picchu for an incredible first glance at the site. You will spend the afternoon alongside your guide at some of the most notable monuments and relics, including the Principal Temple, the Temple of Three Windows, The Royal Tomb, the Houses of the Guards, and the Gateway to the Old City. You can look out on the massive, Andean peaks and the warm hues of the horizon, which will seem just beyond reach. In the evening, you will return to Aguas Calientes for a relaxing night in the village's downtown where you will rest up for another thrilling day at the ruins in the morning.

dayInfo.title: Aguas Calientes – Hot Springs of Aguas Calientes
dayInfo.description: Your second day of discovery at the coveted Machu Picchu ruins will bring you to the site of the Sacred Rock and Intihuatana, which is a massive stone that has been formed in the shape of an altar. Both places allude to an Inca history that is rich with spiritual practices. Many historians believe that Sacred Rock was created as a geographical representation of the surrounding terrain while others assert that it was used for astrological study. Regardless, both serve as prime examples of Inca design and their acute stonework abilities. Later in the day, you will have the option to summit Huayna Picchu, which is an impressive mountain peak that sits at Machu Picchu's rear. The steep climb, though strenuous, rewards its hikers with breathtaking views of the outstretched valley below. For those travelers opting not to make the climb, you will have additional time to tour the ruins and explore the final portion of the Inca Trail. In the afternoon, you will return to the base city for a soothing dip in the medicinal hot springs that gave the city its name. You will climb the secluded path that leads to the steamy water's edge. There, you can relax your muscles and unwind. Once you have dried off and worked up an appetite, you will stroll to the lively, central plaza for a three-course meal of classic Andean dishes like the patasca , which is a corn-based soup. You may also choose from a variety of hearty vegetables, beef or chicken, and potato medleys.

dayInfo.title: Madre de Dios – Arrival in Jungle and Indigenous Fruit Sampler
dayInfo.description: In the morning, you will have to say goodbye to the wonder and awe of the Andes Mountains and set out for the beauty and mystery of the secluded Amazon Rainforest. You will first board the scenic train back to Cusco where you will then board a short flight as you set out for the Madre De Dios region of the Peruvian Amazon. As you touch down, you will be welcomed with wafts of fresh air and the vivacious coos, squeals, and hums of diverse wildlife. Your expert guide will accompany you by land and by water as you set out on a beautiful riverboat cruise, which is destined for your intimate lodge accommodations that are hidden away in the thick foliage that is symbolic of the Amazon. You will settle into your luxury hotel as you lay out on your shaded balcony or sway in your comfortably private hammocks. In the afternoon, you will meet a local food expert who will teach you about the delicious and colorful fruit of the Amazon. You can sample the dark green, mouth-watering limes as you bite into the sweet custard of the creamy, white chirimoya. Watch as your instructor cuts open the outer green shell of the guava to reveal a vibrant pink inside. The pepino melon and starchy lucuma are also local favorites. You will join your guide and food instructor as you learn to press the fruits into refreshingly, sweet juices to enjoy on your sun-kissed patio.

dayInfo.title: Madre de Dios – Hiking Trail Expedition and Amazonian Cooking Class
dayInfo.description: On day two of your expedition through the Amazonian Jungle, you will meet your guide for an exciting day of sightseeing. You will explore trails near your campsite that wind through thick foliage and pass by the dwellings of some of the region's most fascinating animals, including everything from agile spider monkeys to neon-colored tree frogs. You will forge a path to several lookout towers that are buried deep within the forest for unparalleled views. Then, you will hop aboard your riverboat cruise where you will travel to the macaw clay licks. As you glide across the swift waters, you can catch a glimpse of the stunning technicolor hues of the macaw bird. Watch as they soar to the peak of the clay lick and perch with dozens of vibrantly colored, feathered birds. Grab a pair of binoculars or look through your guide's telescope for the best look. Later in the day, you will make your way from water to land as you deboard at a scenic alcove with large shady green leaves and foliage that will be bursting with pinks and yellows. You can listen to the hot spring streams as they cascade from cliffs to the serene basins below, and gather as a group to learn about traditional cuisine in the Amazon. Among the region's staple foods is the plantain, which serves as a base in many dishes. Here, you will meet your expert chef from the previous day who will teach you the best revered of all Amazonian dishes: juanes. This delicious meal includes cooked rice that is combined with grilled chicken and wrapped tightly in banana leaves and grilled to perfection. You will sample the dish to satisfy your Amazonian cravings.

dayInfo.title: Madre de Dios – Ziplining and Conservation Center Visit
dayInfo.description: Your final day in the Amazon will be all about thrill and adventure. You will begin your day with a fresh fruit juice atop your balcony. Then, you will meet your guide below and depart for an adrenaline rush unlike any other. Here, you will set out on a short hike until you come upon the massive stretch of zipline across the treetops. One by one, you will mount the zipline and whiz along the jungle's beautiful canopy layer as you listen to the rustling leaves as spider monkeys shift around you and swing from the swaying branches. You can take mental photos of the gorgeous riverway in the distance and the towering timbers beyond. In the afternoon and after a light lunch at your lodge, you will join your guide at a nearby conservation center where you will learn about the work students, scientists, researchers, and volunteer activists who commit to the Rainforest’s preservation in order to preserve the jungle and its wildlife. You can meet the critters who call the center home before they are rehabilitated and then released once more into the wild. You can also take a short hike with a conservation center staff to spot rare reptiles and camouflaged insects in their natural habitat. As day turns to evening, you will retreat to your lodge for a delectable dinner of inchicapi , which is a coup that is prepared with chicken, peanuts, cilantro, and cassava.

dayInfo.title: Lima – Connect to International Flights Home
dayInfo.description: After a light breakfast, you must say your parting goodbyes to your expert chef and the beauty of the Amazon beyond. You will board your private transport for one last look at the region's jaw-dropping landscapes before winding down narrow mountain roads as cascading streams hug the cliffside beneath you. You will snake your way through the cloud forest as the morning mist wakes sleeping foliage. Finally, you will return to Cusco where you will catch a regional flight to Lima and connect to your international flights home. You can wave to your guide out the plane window as you depart a country with a storied past, intriguing present, and hopeful future in the years to come.
